author: {'steamid': '76561198089294152', 'num_games_owned': 197, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 610, 'last_played': 1709581235}
review:
Played it, didn't like it, too boring, too random. Now I played again after reading a guide and have lot's more fun now.

Roguelikes need to be demanding. I have played games like FTL, Slay the Spire or Noita, so I don't mind difficult games. However, for me there is just not enough stuff going on in Out There to motivate finding out how to not die after a few jumps. The general game loop is a bit boring as well. However, overall and when you know what you are doing it can be a nice "just one more round" game.

Don't know the price, but if you like round based roguelike and don't mind an experience that is more chilled than FTL, you could give this one here a try for around 10 Dollars.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132995625', 'num_games_owned': 1414, 'num_reviews': 754, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1704840973}
review:
[h1] Out There: Î© Edition [/h1]
Space adventure from 2015.
6,050th rating for you.

You are an astronaut waking up from cryonics. But not in the solar system, but... somewhere out there... in a distant and unknown part of the galaxy. In Out There you have to survive, repair your ship with what you collect while floating in space, and find suitable planets to live on to replenish your oxygen supplies. (Developer)

An almost 4X, almost visual novel "adventure game" in almost comic style awaits you. Wanderlust and longing for home at the same time.

It is also more precise:
You start with a small spacer, which is not that small, but soon turns out to be too small for the variety of technology you would like to install. But the cosmic space is also so cold and big. Not only that, it is also a rich source of the raw materials you need. It's just stupid that you can't take everything with you. Yes, the spacer is too small, a larger one is needed. There are various spaceships, more than you, as an experienced captain, can use to start.

Which brings us to the game principle:
There are many, many solar systems that you can visit and many more planets, as well as other interesting things to explore. You are free to choose where you want to go, but it makes sense to keep a specific goal in mind. I did this for almost 7 hours, it doesn't get boring and remains interesting.

The graphics are ok and the game consists largely of text, which is extremely well done and incredibly diverse. Otherwise, exploring anything and everything you can find.
You can use a simple but well thought-out management system. The use of raw materials is also very well thought out.

I don't want to reveal any more here.
It would be a shame to take away the aha effect.
So have fun with this unusually good space epic.
 
My group and my archive with over 6,050 reviews here: https://steamcommunity.com/groups/hoi4deu

Weltraum Abenteuer von 2015.
6.050th Bewertung fÃ¼r euch.

Sie sind ein Astronaut und erwachen aus der Kryonik. Aber nicht im Sonnensystem, sondern ... irgendwo drauÃŸen ... in einem fernen und unbekannten Teil der Galaxie. In â€Out Thereâ€œ mÃ¼ssen Sie Ã¼berleben, Ihr Schiff instand setzen, mit dem, was Sie im Weltall treibend sammeln, und geeignete Planeten zum Leben finden, um Ihre SauerstoffvorrÃ¤te wieder aufzufÃ¼llen. (Entwickler)

Ein fast 4X, fast Visual Novel "Adventure Game" in fast Comic Style erwartet euch. Fernweh und Sehnsucht nach der Heimat zugleich.

Es geht auch genauer:
Starten tust du mit einem kleinen Raumer, der gar nicht so klein ist, sich aber bald als zu klein erweist, fÃ¼r die Vielzahl der Technik die du gerne verbauen wÃ¼rdest Wollen. Der Weltenraum ist aber auch sowas von kalt und groÃŸ. Nicht nur das, er ist auch eine ergiebige Quelle von Rohstoffen die man so braucht. Dumm nur das du nicht alles mitnehmen kannst. Ja genau der Raumer ist zu klein, es muss ein grÃ¶ÃŸerer her. Es gibt diverse Raumer, mehr als du als erfahrener KapitÃ¤n zum Starten nutzen kannst. 

Wobei wir bei dem Spielprinzip angekommen wÃ¤ren:
Es gibt sehr, sehr viele Sonnensysteme die du Ansteuern kannst und noch viel mehr Planeten, dazu kommen noch weitere interessante Dinge zum Erkunden. Du kannst frei WÃ¤hlen wohin du willst, aber sinnvoll ist es ein bestimmtes Ziel im Auge zu behalten. Ich hab das knapp 7 Stunden lang gemacht, es wird nicht Langweilig und bleibt interessant. 

Die Grafik ist ok und das Spiel besteht zu einem groÃŸen Teil aus Text, dieser ist auÃŸerordentlich gut gemacht und unfassbar vielfÃ¤ltig. Ansonsten Erkundung von allem und jedem was du finden kannst.
Ein simples aber gut durchdachtes Management System kannst du Nutzen. Die Rohstoff Nutzung ist ebenfalls sehr gut durchdacht.

Mehr will ich hier nicht Verraten. 
WÃ¤r doch schade euch den "Aha" Effekt zu Nehmen.
Also sehr viel SpaÃŸ mit diesem ungewÃ¶hnlich guten Weltraum Epos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016389716', 'num_games_owned': 3162, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 4780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4780, 'last_played': 1701894991}
review:
This game captures the dread of exploring the endless unknown of the space pretty well. The game keeps you on your toes even when you have end game ship and tech, because you are always only a couple careless jumps away from your untimely demise. I'd recommend referencing the random event cheat sheet on github to mitigate the frustration though.  
I have to admit I began playing this only to try and fill my unsatisfied desire for space exploration after the big disappointment that was Starfield. And to me, this game did the trick. Thank you, mi-clos devs!

author: {'steamid': '76561199228737537', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1699246294}
review:
Ein Raumfahrer, verschollen zwischen den Sternen, fÃ¼hrt ein Tagebuch. Deshalb besteht auch diese Rezension aus gesammelten EindrÃ¼cken.
Erster Eindruck (nach 2,6 Stunden): Fantastisch!
Nach 8,9 Stunden mein erstes "Game over", also auch herausfordernd.
2.Versuch, diesmal auf "leicht", immer noch fordernd, und die Geschichte lÃ¤uft vollkommen anders ab. Andere Technologien, Raumschiffe, Ereignisse, Welten, Aliens.
Und schon sind 28 Stunden vergangen...
Zum ersten Mal durchgespielt! Aber es gibt mindestens noch 4 weitere MÃ¶glichkeiten das Spiel zu beenden. Die will ich alle schaffen!
Also kann man auch im Modus "Leicht" verlieren. Ziemlich leicht.
Meine Begeisterung hat etwas nachgelassen. Der Zufallsfaktor spielt eine zu groÃŸe Rolle. Auch wenn man sich bemÃ¼ht, so gut wie mÃ¶glich zu entscheiden, kann eine Kombination von ungÃ¼nstigen Zufallsereignissen das Aus bedeuten. Dies sorgt natÃ¼rlich fÃ¼r enorme Spannung, aber auch fÃ¼r enormen Frust.
GroÃŸe SchwÃ¤che des Spiels: Selbst auf Stufe leicht zu leichtes Ausscheiden. Da nimmt die Frustration Ã¼berhand. Schade. Mit mehr Optionen hinsichtlich der Schwierigkeit hÃ¤tte es das Zeug zu meinem Lieblingsspiel. Aber so... Die Kaufempfehlung bleibt trotzdem. Solange man es gÃ¼nstig kriegt. Alleine die PlanetenoberflÃ¤chen sind schon ein paar Euro wert.
"ZufÃ¤llig" kommen direkt nacheinander Zufallsereignisse, die einen erledigen, egal was man vorher fÃ¼r richtige oder falsche Entscheidungen traf. "Ereignisse", die von der Story her absolut keinen Sinn ergeben. "Er" muss Ballast Ã¼ber Bord werfen, und wÃ¤hlt das allerwertvollste anstatt unnÃ¼tzes Zeug. Ich kann mich auch nicht mit dieser Figur identifizieren, wenn sie z.B. aus Wut unersetzbare Aggregate zerstÃ¶rt. WÃ¼rde ich mich so verhalten, hÃ¤tte mein PC dieses Spiel nicht Ã¼berstanden. Ein Ã¤sthetisch so schÃ¶nes Spiel mit tollen Ideen, mit derartig Ã¼blen Spielmechanismen zu versauen, dafÃ¼r sollten sich die Entwickler schÃ¤men.
Meine Beziehung zu diesem Spiel ist wie eine heftige Liebe auf den ersten Blick, die sich schlieÃŸlich in Hass verwandelt. Ich bezweifle, daÃŸ ich "ihr" noch eine Chance gebe.
Eine Kaufempfehlung kann ich nicht mehr geben. AnfÃ¤ngliche Euphorie bezahlt man mit zu viel anschlieÃŸendem Frust. Es ist zu traurig, zu sehen, wie soviel Potential versaut wird.
Eine andere Rezension vergleicht dieses Spiel mit Roulette. Nicht ganz passend, den beim Roulette weiÃŸ man wenigstens innerhalb einer Minute, dass man wieder verloren hat. Hier kann man dabei Stunden verschwenden.
Wenn man es schafft, sein Raumschiff gut auszubauen, verbessern sich die Chancen. Aber so weit muss man erst mal kommen.
Wenn man es wider erwarten doch geschafft hat, ist die Freude natÃ¼rlich groÃŸ. Ich gebe "ihr" doch noch eine Chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072852115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1095, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1095, 'last_played': 1693532403}
review:
I got this game because I'm a fan of FTL, and I think it holds up in comparison. There's a huge variety of random events in the game, both positive and negative. I played the game on easy and found it challenging, but in a good way.

One complaint is that the UI is really annoying. There are no keyboard shortcuts, and the different UI elements are on opposite sides of the screen. When one considers how the game is repetitive and entirely pointer based, it really adds up over time, especially on a large monitor. Simple tasks take multiple clicks, and that annoyance bothered me during some of the longer playthroughs. No RNG is going to have a great story, but I was kind of bored with it by the end.

But hey, the game isn't expensive, and there's a ton of replay-ability. Overall, I would recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198352551562', 'num_games_owned': 204, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 742, 'last_played': 1693143342}
review:
Out There is a top Roguelike game. It has simple mechanics, smooth gameplay, lots of options for completing a run. Can easily dump 4-5 hours into this game on a lazy Saturday afternoon like I have multiple times. Be warned, the game is mighty tough! I've only ever won on easy, and it was anything but.

I wish tech was a little easier to come by, but that'd be the only blemish in a otherwise solid game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971546969', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 900, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 900, 'last_played': 1692477554}

Puedes morir sin remedio si no tienes los planetas necesarios cerca. TambiÃ©n puedes quedarte atascado si te teletransportas a un grupo de estrellas lejos del resto. La interfaz estÃ¡ demasiado dispersa y tienes que mover el ratÃ³n de extremo a extremo de la pantalla.

author: {'steamid': '76561198155055479', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1671308553}
review:
I honestly like this thing, and I can see myself using it more.

But if you want an objective review, Our There cannot be reccomended.

The progression is all over the place, random events that will simply end the run and zero turorial for a game that believe me, even if so simple, should absolutely explain to the player what are the priorities to survive and explain crucial techs.

Usually your runs will end because you are not able to jump to other systems, close to reaching the main red objective.
The "game" is not even able to bring you to the game over screen automatically: you often have to "give up" by yourself.

Almost outrageous, and not in a good sense.

About the price, it's well worth in my opinion 2,49 â‚¬, in other words the usual "sale price". 

15 â‚¬ for this? Not even in another universe.

author: {'steamid': '76561199183551133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4487, 'last_played': 1687542885}
review:
Good game. It scratches the casual game itch.  More than likely you got here because it was supposed to be like another game.  Its not. Best description, I can come up with is: mix of rogue-like and rogue-lite, space adventure, resource manager, has a plot of sorts and plot is not bad,  very limited crafting, worth the money, replayable.

There is real ROGUE (as in the rogue game) RNG in the game. Utterly random. It will frustrate the hell out of you.  But the rogue-lite part is that if you finish a quest you can get a different starting ship.  The best ship to start with is the one with three orbs on it.  That ship has a lot of space on it to stock up on fuel (and future ores for new tech), conserves your oxygen and has medium shielding to help conserve your iron resource. This starting ship helps to mitigate the brutal RNG of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198274927731', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1677731700}

author: {'steamid': '76561197992370937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 2183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2183, 'last_played': 1677922268}
review:
This is a very cautious "Yes".

The game can be very fun, it's relatively small and you'll get the hang of the mechanics pretty quickly.
But finishing it will be brutal, RNG waits for you around every corner trying to mess up your runs!
And a LOT of the mechanics in the game are tied to RNG in some way or another.

Expect many restarts and perhaps some raging, but once you do get one of the 5 possible endings the satisfaction makes it worth it.

Do not buy if this sounds like something you won't finish.
Also, the price is a bit steep for the amount of gameplay, I'd wait for a sale.

Finished 100% in ~35 hours (all possible endings and achievements).
A single run can take anywhere from 5 minutes up to ~1-3 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113192300', 'num_games_owned': 1101, 'num_reviews': 254, 'playtime_forever': 582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 582, 'last_played': 1524038687}
review:
Here are several reasons to play Out There:

Who doesn't love being lost in space with limited resources and no one to talk to? Out There puts you in just that situation, and it's surprisingly fun!

You get to explore the galaxy and discover all sorts of strange planets and alien life forms. Just watch out for the ones that want to eat you.

Resource management has never been so important. You'll have to balance your oxygen, fuel, and supplies carefully if you want to survive long enough to find your way back home.

The game features a beautiful art style that really captures the vastness and mystery of space. Plus, the soundtrack is out of this world.

Who needs a plot when you can just wander aimlessly through the void of space? Okay, there is actually a plot, but it's more about the journey than the destination.

You never know what you're going to encounter next in Out There. Maybe you'll stumble upon an ancient alien artifact, or maybe you'll just find a bunch of space rocks. Either way, it's an adventure!

The game is a great way to pass the time on long space flights. Just make sure you don't get too engrossed in it and forget to fly the ship.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088495820', 'num_games_owned': 1740, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1601497131}
review:
Interesting game brought low by a high amount of bugs. Which I would normally put up with, but in this case they kill entire runs by deleting your progress through savegame corruption, ships bugging out, etc.

While minor bug fixes were regular for a while, these larger bugs have not been addressed in years.

The game requires many runs to really see a lot of it, so that is a frustrating combination. I recommend checking out the bug report thread in the discussion forum before considering a purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006268674', 'num_games_owned': 5624, 'num_reviews': 281, 'playtime_forever': 1023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 478, 'last_played': 1676172654}
review:
Spaceship resource manager. If you run out of resources, it's game over. Try and make it to as many planets as possible, and discover new ships, species and ship upgrades while mining and probing planets for goodies. It's an ok game but gets kind of old quickly. The lack of depth makes it difficult to commit time to this game.

6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198428702035', 'num_games_owned': 1705, 'num_reviews': 664, 'playtime_forever': 98, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1671561979}
review:
ESP:
Es un juegazo, sin embargo tiene una dificultad tremenda, y no es una dificultad justa, dependes de suerte, a veces te podes quedar varado porque no te alcanza el potencia para viajar a la estrella siguiente, o se te rompe una parte y no tenes el material para para repararla, etcetera. Recomendado en oferta.

ENG:
It is a great game, however it has an excessive difficulty, and it is not a fair difficulty, you depend on luck, sometimes you can get stranded because you do not have enough power to travel to the next star, or you break a part and you do not have the material to repair it, and so on. Recommended on offer.

author: {'steamid': '76561199183468063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1669842811}
review: Gameplay gets very repetitive after a couple of hours and overall, succeeding in this game is way too dependant on RNG. Wish there was a mechanic to reward surviving longer in the game, like maybe upgrading your ship to increase survivability the longer you play (the only upgrade mechanic currently available is you can come across and board a new ship, but again that mechanic is dependant on RNG).

author: {'steamid': '76561197968315188', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1670766155}
review: Hardly even a game.  You are completely at the mercy of a series of random events.  It may as well be called a 'visual novel' as you do little more than click on something to move to the next page.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047728479', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1669586394}
review:
Pros - might be an interesting story

Cons - I'll never get to read it because the game kills you with a random arbitrary event at every opportunity, that you can do nothing at all about. If you like dying over and over again with nothing to show for it and having to start again from scratch each time, this could be the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137560643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 701, 'last_played': 1659399624}
review:
Loved the story, the art, but maaaan, the RNG makes it almost impossible to beat.

You may had a good run, a good ship + a couple of good tech and Omega stacked up, but RNG comes in: Bad random events makes you lose Fuel, the next 2-3 solar systems dont have gas giants/they have a few but they are poor in Hydrogen and dont provide Helium, (from this point it seems that Helium ran out from this cluster of stars..) you try desperately and burn your Omegas for extra fuel, but the 4th solar system it's again poor in Fuel and you are done for, restart again.

But hey, not only with Fuel, my last run I went through 12 solar systems, and NOT EVEN ONE of those had a habitable planet, and by the end even got a random event that got me -20 Oxygen and just like that I lost.

Started playing on mobile on 2017 and you could win it with a little of a learning curve when the option of (Any solar systems you leave, turns into a black hole but ++ resources the rest of the run) was available, but now its pure luck even if you have won and achieved a couple of endings before.

For new buyers, try Easy Mode, might get playabe.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009080626', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 2089, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2089, 'last_played': 1659299251}
review: Geniales spiel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001437005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1657909765}
review: This game has only one mechanic - inventory management. Once you figure that system out, there are no significant decisions and outcomes are decided purely by RNG. I can't imagine playing this more than 10 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201668110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1628276638}
review: Look, I really admire the atmosphere this game has, and there is nothing wrong with the mechanics in principle. The problem is, your success and failure are entirely dependent on luck, which means you will most likely fail. A lot. From your FTL drive getting destroyed in a way you could not have avoided. It's just not worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561199004665265', 'num_games_owned': 35, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1665431156}

author: {'steamid': '76561198817694069', 'num_games_owned': 111, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 446, 'last_played': 1673205157}
review: Justo cuando crees que todo va bien, el juego te deforma y acabas agotando tus recursos. Siempre prefieran perder recursos que deformarse. El juego es un 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198951080530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1657044492}
review: Simple but addictive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007042683', 'num_games_owned': 1313, 'num_reviews': 215, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1655244560}
review: A great idea for a game, but there's too much rolling the dice (i.e. RNG). Apparently the devs have said this is by design, because it's you trying to survive a vast, unknown universe, but I didn't see anywhere in the store page where it said "your hard work may be wiped out by bad luck. Try again!" Personally, losing games to RNG doesn't make me want to keep playing them. However, given that this game has so much to offer, including four endings, and the fact that I got the game on sale, I'm going to give it more of a shot than I usually do a game that turns me off this quickly. If you can find a coupon for the game or wait for a sale, then I'd recommend it. I wouldn't pay full price, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102670115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 707, 'last_played': 1645286464}
review:
Found this quite enjoyable actually. Would have never come across it without the coupon I'd imagine but I'm glad I did.

To start, this can be quite difficult. Traveling through the cosmos with diminishing supplies and potential threats in each system can be quite stressful. Always having to plan ahead as you manage your resources because they could be stripped from you any turn for any reason making your next decision worse. So many random sorts of events and triggers that could either help you or basically end a run. Thankfully there is the cemetery feature that allows you to come across your past failures and could be the reason you complete the mission this time around. While there is a lot of random events throughout your travels the interaction between species is quite limited. There is a lot of different looking species in many different looking places however they all share two separate scenarios with little variation. The rewards are great for successful and even failed interactions but once again the very next system you travel to can take that all away and more.

Overall this game great. If there were anything I could change it would be the interaction with other species and for it to have as much effort and variation put in as there is when you travel system to system, sometimes even planet to planet. Maybe some more music? I'm not sure myself but what's present is nice but I don't believe I have heard it change much and you spend a decent amount of time reading and analyzing things. Otherwise great job guys.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014447281', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1694455278}
review:
This is a great game for the price! 10/10

TL:DR, it's a very entertaining, easy to play, arcade style space survival game. I definitely recommend getting this. 

Don't get me wrong, its not a AAA title by any stretch, but the story is interesting, the gameplay is simplistic but its super easy to get into, and it works well. If you've ever played FTL: Faster than Light, this game is like a lighter rendition on the limited resources aspect of that.

review:
Les 20 premiÃ¨res minutes sont assez bien, on apprend Ã  gÃ©rer ses ressources, Ã  faire ses calculs pour aller le plus loin possible... On pardonne les fautes d'orthographe dans le texte, la syntaxe parfois douteuse, on en fait tous des fautes... On admire les paysages des diffÃ©rentes planÃ¨tes...

Et puis vient le temps de la dÃ©bÃ¢cle, en boucle, vous pouvez avoir toutes les ressources nÃ©cessaire, le plus grand des vaisseaux, il suffit d'un Ã©vÃ©nement "alÃ©atoire" pour que vous perdiez instantanÃ©ment la partie. 

Donc oui j'y ai jouÃ© beaucoup plus que 20 minutes, mais c'est plus par frustration que par plaisir, moins de 10% des joueurs ont fini le jeu.

Je vous laisse, j'ai Crying Suns & Bad North qui m'attendent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022950565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 2057, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2057, 'last_played': 1641930662}
review:
I interpreted this as a resource management game and didn't like it due to the RNG element. Without much spoiler here is the issue. Your ship requires two different resources ( oxygen and fuel ) and hull strength which is basically health that can be repaired with some minable metals. While you are in a star system you may need to mine for one of these resources; however every move through and between systems and planets burns fuel and oxygen, landing or getting into an orbit of a planetary body or star also burns fuel and damages hull, mining burns fuel and random events might burn all three resources. Above all of these your equipment also can be damaged, these equipment are used to move the ship and mine resources. 

 So this game comes to prioritise certain resources to be on the ship inventory all the time. Otherwise if the engine or the drill fails and there is no required metal to fix it or if you run out of fuel there is no alternative and you have to restart the game. This is where rng comes into the play. Minable resource types change with every planet or star. While there are certain group parameters, determining which body holds what resources and by which amount is based on rng. So even if you play safe your resource burn speed could be more than what you can scavenge or mine. You can fail even before you start.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993245965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1640443237}
review:
The RNG is not a flaw, it's the point. The game is about coping with impossible circumstances as best as you can. Death is expected, and survival is a happy triumph. Good decision making is necessary but not sufficient, because the universe really is out to kill you.

I love the writing and the universe. Great sci fi.

author: {'steamid': '76561199020934809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1523, 'last_played': 1638685815}
review:
Out There: Omega Edition is not a good game. In fact, it is an unbelievably terrible game built around a nifty concept, and wrapped in some aesthetic art. Sadly, the concept never paid off, due to its horrible implementation. It makes one wonder whether anyone bothered to playtest the game before release, and why it wasn't fixed after release.

Out There wants to be a tough-as-nails hardcore roguelike, but it only succeeds in being tediously difficult. It is in fact the worst roguelike that I've ever played: You always start in the same location, stars are always in the same locations, the majority of objectives are always in the same locations, and events always trigger at the same locations, etc.
If you don't mix the experience up by randomizing things, it becomes boring. It's like running a marathon, but every time you near a milestone, out of nowhere a randomly selected onlooker beans you in the head and drags you back to the starting line.
When RNG is utilized, it's in all the wrong places, and it's brutal. In fact, random events are often so brutal that I suspect they are not truly random either:  You are getting relatively far this run? A random event destroys both your interstellar and interplanetary engines simultaneously. End of run. Start over. Three out of twenty inventory slots contain something irreplaceable? A random event wipes exactly those three slots. The odds of that happening are 1 in 1140, yet it happens again and again and again. 

Beating the game doesn't feel much more satisfying than dying, because your save file gets scrubbed to prevent you from reloading and trying a different win condition. No, you have to do it all over again, every agonizing and infuriating second of it. Over and over and over again.
It took me 25 hours across 17 playthroughs to get 100% completion. Afterwards I cannot imagine touching it ever again. Don't do that to yourself. 
Spare your sanity by frequently copying the  save file from AppData\Local\MiClos Studio\OutThereOmegaEdition\outthereomega.sav . However often you now think frequently means, that's not often enough.
Better yet, do not buy this game, unless it is to financially reward and incentivize the developers for selling it DRM-free on the Humble Store, rather than to play it.
I hear that the demo for the sequel, Out There: Oceans of Time, while still too unforgiving to be enjoyable for anyone who isn't a masochist, has less atrocious RNG and adds a lot more varied content to break up the tedium. Go play that instead, it's free.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969199671', 'num_games_owned': 258, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 2128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2128, 'last_played': 1634659533}
review:
The most miserable game I've ever had the misfortune of getting addicted to.
 
- It's stupid difficult, you'll have to use guides to navigate your way through all the unfortunate events that might occur while star hopping. And even then you will struggle. 
- Every action takes up about five mouse clicks unnecessarily, continually navigating excessive UI.
- You're always one false move away from getting utterly destroyed by RNGesus

Basically all the pleasure in this game comes from inexplicably escaping certain death, as opposed to having actual fun.

review:
I bought Out There hoping for another FTL, and boy was I disappointed. Heavier on narrative, and lacking combat, Out There is crushingly difficult game of exploration and resource management, which on Normal will see you routinely thrashed by the RNG. Easy mode is more rewarding, allowing you to actually progress towards the gameâ€™s goals, but remains troubled by sophomoric writing, tonally all over the place, in a silly off-brand Star Wars sci-fi setting.

Stranded far from Earth (Out There!) by one of those pesky cryosleep malfunctions, you play a lonesome astronaut hoping to return home. Along the way, youâ€™ll encounter a mishmash of space plagues, talking crystals, space whales, solar flares, meteorite showers and space bees which constantly peck away at your hull, fuel and oxygen reserves. Stumble across a space station or planet where you can replenish your supplies, and youâ€™ll outlast entropy a little longer. Even better, you might scrounge up a technology or stumble across a superior ship which gives you a fighting chance at navigating the more distant reaches of the overworld map. With little in the way of tactics or skill to guide your decision-making, however, every jump is really just a roll of the dice. Most likely, youâ€™ll die repeatedly, and return to the start of the map to try your luck again. It wonâ€™t be long before you get sick of meeting the same talking crystals and space bees in a newly-randomised iteration of the galaxy.

Out Thereâ€™s patchy prose seems to strive for a sense of lonelieness and wonder, and occasionally succeeds. Progress is all the sweeter, when it comes, for the otherwise bleak and unforgiving voyage, even if player agency has little to do with it.  Mostly, however, Out There feels like a low-budget, less well-written FTL, with that gameâ€™s tremendous combat and ship-management mechanics and superb soundtrack removed. Thereâ€™s little here to recommend; check out Hades for a vastly superior narrative-driven roguelike.

author: {'steamid': '76561198848779778', 'num_games_owned': 67, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 2930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2930, 'last_played': 1629736978}
review:
Now that I finally got all achievements, I can say this is a great game!

In Out There - Omega you get to explore many star systems and gather resources that will help you achieve one of five missions. 

The first jumps will be mainly based on luck, as the first ship just won't be enough to get you far, but once you find the best ship (Garden Ship, trust me) and build the right modules to almost max power, environment and resistance, the game will run pretty smooth. 

Nice soundtrack, atmosphere and plot, Out There - Omega also gives subtle life lessons, which I quite didn't expect in this game when I bought it.

So yeah, I enjoyed the game very much!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993698924', 'num_games_owned': 566, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1629793339}
review:
Once again, I'd love to give neutral verdict. It's not a bad game. It's just really basic and repetitive. Jump to a solar system, land on planet to drill/probe and get some resources. Once you've visited all planets, jump to another solar system. At some point you run out of resources for fuel or hull and die.

There are three types of planets, some random encounters. No combat, no quests to speak of. You just fly and fly and hope for the best. It was fun for about 2 hours and then I couldn't refund. Wouldn't buy again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093178235', 'num_games_owned': 1233, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 2241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2282, 'last_played': 1628409940}
review:
Es un juego sobretodo de gestiÃ³n de recursos, Combustible, OxÃ­geno, Casco. Al principio tienes que conseguir Combustible TOOOOOODO el tiempo, y tienes que tener algo de suerte. Es de los 3 el que baja mÃ¡s rÃ¡pido.

- Lo primordial es construir mejoras del apartado "Fuerza" (Reactor Subespacial, Generador de Pozos, Stasis Pau y Velas Solares) en la que puedas tener mÃ¡s "Fuerza", para asÃ­ usar menos comBustible y poder viajar mÃ¡s rÃ¡pido.  Cuando tienes estas mejoras hechas, podrÃ¡s hacer todas las misiones.

- Lo segundo es cambiar de nave. Elegir una con mÃ¡s capacidad o una con buena Fuerza. Hay una nave triangular que tiene solo de base 8 de Fuerza (con la que yo he terminado los 5finales), cuando las demÃ¡s tienen entre 2 y 4. No tiene mucha capacidad (17 Slots), con lo que entre mejoras y demÃ¡s solo tendrÃ¡s unos 5-6espacios para Recursos, pero puedes usar otras Naves abandonadas como AlmacÃ©n. Con ella no pararÃ¡s de viajar casi indefinidamente. Con el Combustible necesita H y He, que se pueden conseguir en los Planetas Gaseosos.

- Es recomendable ir guardando las partidas cuando consigas una buena nave. Porque a la mÃ­nima los Eventos te destrozan o te mandan a tomar por culo y no puedes ni moverte. Buscad en guÃ­as como hacerlo.

- GeoescÃ¡ner. Es una mejora indispensable. Te dice los elementos de cada planeta, sin que tengas que bajar o tirar sonda, y asÃ­ te ahorras muchÃ­simo combustible.

- InterferÃ³metro. Tb una mejora muy Ãºtil. Te dice el tipo de planetas de cada Estrella, Gaseoso, Rocoso o JardÃ­n. Con lo que te ahorras mucho combustible.

- Conseguir Omega tambiÃ©n es muy importante, conseguir entre 15 y 20 tendrÃ¡s un seguro de vida infinita. Seguir las preguntas de las GuÃ­as de Lenguaje serÃ¡ muy Ãºtil.

- Los Eventos son muy random.  Se pueden anotar todos (como yo hice, anotÃ© unos 130 diferentes), para asÃ­ no depender tanto de la suerte. Llega un punto que las mejoras de Tech y Omega que consigues en estos Eventos (y que no se carguen tu nave o te roben elementos cada 2x3) se hace muy importante.

Es un buen juego de gestiÃ³n, pero se basa demasiado en no morir por falta de 1 elemento, de Combustible como no. Muy entretenido.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057615874', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1558905110}
review:
The mining / resource gathering mechanics left me exhausted weighing if I should use more fuel at a time to dig up materials or if it was better spent spamming 1 fuel until there was "no resources left on an entire planet"

Felt contrived and it really did pull me out of the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080800178', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1620257357}
review: I wanted to like this game, I really did.  Great writing, good concept.  But it's too easy to lose an hour's progress just because the RNG hates you for a little bit.  If I want to play a game where the dice hate me in space leading to my death, there's always Tharsis where I can at least see the dice.   I liked everything else about the game, from graphics to chemical elements in cargo, but I just didn't enjoy playing it.  No sense of progress means no dopamine hit, I guess.

author: {'steamid': '76561198279732975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 3468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1627131679}
review: Controls work much better on phone and can be annoying on PC. Otherwise a great game so still a positive review

author: {'steamid': '76561198080285965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1625829187}
review:
Brilliant game!
FTL feels easy and predictable in comparison. Being out there is hard. 
You are alone, you have very limited cargo space and you never know what lies ahead. (My impression is, most people who complain about the game just expect it to be easy)
It conveys the utter vastness and miracle of space just wonderfully - if you let it, by actually paying attention to the story elements and not just clicking through ASAP.
A game for people who apreciate good story, atmosphere and challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993062418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 892, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 892, 'last_played': 1624594402}
review:
Haven't played in years, give it a go. After ~ten star systems, zero planets with oxygen. I run out of air. An escape pod item saves me and allows me to continue with only drive systems - no way to get any resources to repair stuff. Then in the very next system I get the blurb 'I hurt myself on a pipe and got mad and broke another pipe. I am stupid.' Space folder broken, no way to repair. 

Why would a man in such a tenuous situation throw a tantrum and destroy the only thing protecting him? It's not just that the game is dominated by chance, a glorified slot machine. But that writing is just jarringly sloppy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052343234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1650070922}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041533372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1994, 'last_played': 1706062551}
review:
Don't let the low steam game time fool you... I've poured a few hundred hours into it between steam and my mac account. 
This is an excellent game that I would recommend any sci-fi and resource management-text based adventure games! I find it challenging, and I guarantee you won't get through all the content on your first go. Or the second. OR THE THIRD..... ETC. But it's the unpredictable variety of events, planets, and encounters that keep you focused. Especially considering the multiple endings you can come across!
Give it a shot! An hour is more than enough time to tell whether you're into this style of game or not! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198014296958', 'num_games_owned': 2476, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1623763572}
review:
[u]Negatives:[/u]
[list]
[*] autosave only works when it feels like it, no options to f.e. set interval
[*] no way to manually save
[*] can't go to menu/press escape during tutorial
[*] gets repetitive and boring fast
[*] it looks, feels and plays like a mobile game
[*] feels like a very overpriced tablet port (only costs 5$ on app store, compared to 15$ on Steam)
[/list]

[u]Things to point out:[/u]
[list]
[*] personally I don't like the graphics style, it looks like a 2010s flash game
[*] 2 difficulties: easy and normal
[*] has huge variations in randomness of resources you lose and obtain which can sometimes instantly end the game, just because you had an unlucky roll
[*] it's faster to alt + f4 out of the game than quitting through the menu because for some reason it shows their studio logo for like 5 seconds when closing the game
[/list]


[u]Conclusion:[/u]
not a terrible game but for the price being tripled compared to the mobile version I would dodge it unless you can get it at a 75% or more sale, it's definitely not worth the full 15$.
The lacking feature to manually save cripples your progression and the gameplay itself gets mundane after playing more than 2 hours.
It just feels like an off-brand version of FTL and surprisingly is more expensive than FTL too.

[b]4/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197985829422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1619873924}
review:
As you approach a planet on your third play through you look at your clock. It's been 40 minutes and you haven't felt anything resembling "fun" since you started. Do you A) Uninstall or B) Uninstall and Leave A Bad Review?

The developer found a way to marry the idea of extreme boredom and repetitiveness with random frustration. Future generations will draw inspiration for new and crueler forms of government based on this failure.

review:

The price is also insanely high for such a simplistic mobile game experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152586743', 'num_games_owned': 144, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1611586293}
review:
Due parole per riassumere il gioco: ripetitivo e frustrante. Quando si muore si ha la sensazione costante che non sarebbe stato possibile fare diversamente: l'unico modo per vincere Ã¨ avere fortuna!
Fortuna a trovare sempre abbastanza carburante e materiale di riparazione
Fortuna a ritrovarsi con una navicella decente
Fortuna a non finire in un vicolo cieco e dover tornare indietro, consumando carburante prezioso
Ormai questi giochi li individuo dopo un paio di partite rapide.
Out There Ã¨ una copia concettuale di Faster Than Light. Anche lÃ¬ c'Ã¨ un buon fattore c**o, ma almeno nel frattempo ti diverti.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989380272', 'num_games_owned': 354, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1620756538}
review:
This is a great game to get on sale, but I would not buy it full price. Gameplay starts with choosing a ship which determines how much you can hold, some stats for ship resource usage, and what materials are able to be converted into ship resources (e.g hydrogen can be used as fuel in the standard ship). After this you follow a map of "system" nodes that open to smaller sets of "planet" nodes you can travel between, gather resources from, and interact with aliens on. If you run our of resources or have a bad event, the game is over. 

It's not over the top challenging, but planning and figuring out how to be efficient is definitely important. The random events make it hard to really stick to a plan and often times I end up close to a goal only for something annoying to happen that leads to a loss. I'm not very far in yet so hoping I can unlock more stuff before I move on, but I don't see this being a long term game for me.

Edit: Game is proving more challenging than I thought it would be. I've yet to finish a run, but I've unlocked a bunch of stuff to help mix things up a little. I think this is a 5-8 hour game for myself. I'm starting to lose interest in the gameplay loop for now, but I could see myself coming back to it and tryin to complete some runs

author: {'steamid': '76561198007108285', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1657504264}
review:
Was enjoying my time, barely enough resources to get to the next system as usual, finally out of oxygen when I find a new ship, hell yeah I'm saved. 3 jumps later turns out I'm soft locked can't reach any of the next star systems, so I could choose to die with no oxygen or choose to die without being able to reach anywhere.

This game is otherwise fun and I have a lot more hours that steam isn't registering, must've been on my phone or friends computer. I can't recommend spending hours in the game only to be screwed by a bad RNG roll on the planet set up literally hours into your run you might hit even if you were doing a good job of it.

essentially the random roll for your galaxy at the start of your game can literally lock you out no matter how well your resource management is. I really like this game but every time I come back I hit this same wall, What a shame

author: {'steamid': '76561198010641857', 'num_games_owned': 1536, 'num_reviews': 289, 'playtime_forever': 737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 689, 'last_played': 1618074741}
review:
I get to day 117, im in the cocoon ship, im hiding in an asteroid, I read the text, I try to click OK and.....nothing happens. At all. the game just stay there. giving me the ok button to press and nothing more.

also, achievements dont work, the story is pretty shallow, the options are pretty shallow, the consequences on the options are pretty much random and doesnt make much sense...

I dont know, I dont think this is really a bad game, I think I would recommend it more than not, but it definetely needed more polish that will never get.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124014248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 409, 'playtime_forever': 161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1617452940}
review:
Despite the fact that you pilot a spaceship in this game, Out There features no combat, opting instead for a CYOA style gameplay with events and resource management that's limited to upgrades and survival. 
I found the art and soundtrack to be very nice, but the gameplay is generally shallow and heavily reliant on RNG so I don't really see a reason to play it three more times just for some extra dialogue and a different ending. 
As an example, you have to probe gas giants for fuel, in order to accomplish this you must first randomly find a system with gas giants, then you must spend some fuel and oxygen to get to the planet in question and, finally, select how much fuel you want to spend while probing, which determines how much fuel you can get, but investing more fuel also increases the chances of your probe sustaining damage or breaking. This is by far the most common thing you do in this game and it's basically spending a bunch of resources in hopes of getting some more of the same resources while making a positive return on investment you can then use in order to get to the next star system and repeat the process all over again. The only thing you can do to affect this loop is buy an upgrade that reduces the risk of resource extraction by decreasing resource costs.
Overall, I don't think there's anything outright wrong with Out There, it's just kind of boring because it plays like a flowchart.

review: Ignorant game that promotes nonsensical atheist viewpoints.   Life is everywhere, it is a natural occurrence in creation.   Creativity is 'god', in a word,  Love is the very essence of Divine,  to create life, matter, energy, space itself.  Creativity is to take part of the Divine Plan.   No, I can't click  ''OK'' that life is some sort of ''Accident'' - The Creator decided the universe needed YOU.  Why ?   Well - that's up to you to  decide, to figure out.   The path you make is up to you,  and the mind you have is the tool you are given. <3  LOVE LIFE !  ENJOY EXISTENCE ! :-)   Life is your playground,  make friends and enjoy it while it lasts.  Also includes a bigotry bashes at Catholicism and Christianity.   When  The Way of Love is spelled out easily:   Love ALL.  All Love.   Christ teaches, feeds, and heals - the Good Samaritan Lesson is All of Christianity:  Help  Others.  Loving Kindness.  Mindful Mercy.  Be Kind.   Care.   Heal.   No mythology needed to love, help, feed, and heal others.  ''A New Commandment I give to you: Love One Another."  Yahshua Messiah taught Empathology as a replacement upgrade to mythology.  Love is Real   Faith Hope and Love,  True Love is Eternal.  The Witness to the Truth:  True Love is Real.

review:
AprÃ©s avoir longuement rÃ©flÃ©chie, je pense que je ne recommande pas vraiment ce jeu,je m'explique :
ce jeux est difficile mais ce n'est pas son problÃ¨me, il s'inscrit dans une grande catÃ©gorie qui comprendra des jeux comme xcom ou darkest dungeon par exemple(genre que j'adore !!). lÃ  oÃ¹ est son problÃ¨me, c'est dans l'Ã©volution que le jeu va donner au joueur par rapport au jeu.
C'est-Ã -dire que dans cette catÃ©gorie de jeu, gÃ©nÃ©ralement, la difficultÃ© fera que l'on va perdre et Ãªtre dans des situations critiques mais elles vont nous forger sur comment faire en sorte de ne plus Ãªtre dans cette fameuse situation et ainsi, au travers de la pÃ©dagogie, on obtient la maÃ®trise du jeu or dans out there, celÃ  ne sert Ã  rien.
si je perdait pas mal sur xcom ou darkest dungeon au dÃ©but, et bien aprÃ©s qlqs heures de jeu,j'arrivais Ã  maÃ®trisÃ© asser le jeu pour m'en sortir et pouvoir gagnÃ©, or dans out there, mÃªme aprÃ©s toutes mes heures de jeu,celÃ  ne change rien, perdre y ai toujours aussi facile, entre le fait que mÃªme en sachant exactement oÃ¹ trouvÃ© tel ou tel Ã©lÃ©ment, en connaissant les vaisseaux, en dÃ©couvrant des technologies, et bien souvent on va perdre pour des raisons qui ne changent pas mÃªme avec des connaissances sur le jeu ou l'apprentissage est inutile.
Ne pas avoir la chance de dropper l'Ã©lÃ©ment cruciale pour avancÃ©, oubliÃ© une technologie qui est pourtant cruciale et que je n'ai jamais pu avoir la chance de voir revenir dans une mÃªme run, se retrouver dans une situation avec un vaisseau extraordinaire mais que aucune planÃ¨te n'est Ã  porter pour avancÃ© mÃªme avec deux amÃ©liorateurs de portÃ©e de voyage...etc.
bref tellement de situation aussi absurde dans lesquels on meurt sans pouvoir rien faire. 
je vous recommanderais, si vous voulez jouer Ã  un jeu de ce genre, de meilleurs jeux tel que xcom(1 et 2) ou darkest dungeon(que j'ai dÃ©jÃ  citÃ©) ou encore iratus-lord of the dead,warhammer-mechanicus et blood bowl 2, urtuk ou other side.

author: {'steamid': '76561198180063266', 'num_games_owned': 8840, 'num_reviews': 151, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1615121394}
review:
Unfortunately doesn`t feel like I have any control over what happens in the game. It`s either a slow or rapid dwindling of resources depending on which ship I use and pure luck if you get anywhere or not or find anything useful. Resources feel too limited leading to increasing losses the farther you go until you run out and the addition of dead ends due to jump range kills a run with no chance to recover. I assume there must be an optimal strategy but I`m guessing it must follow a very strict line and I don`t have the time or patience to find out what it is. It`s as if you`re waiting for the stars to align just to have the perfect run and everything else is just doomed. I could also be terrible at it.
Shame, it`s a pretty relaxed game and presentation is decent but the economy is just too frustratingly stingy to make me want to keep trying. I see others have 30+ hours in this game but I don`t think that would be a productive use of my time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092225922', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1666, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 631, 'last_played': 1614817053}
review:
I Played omega edition. I can recommend it only with discount (5-7 USD seems reasonable price considering content)
+ artwork (with exception of alien species design, imho a bit lazy)
+ music 
+ ambient
+ adventures in spaaaace

- rather short
- some frustrating choices made by devs, other reviewers already described them in lenght. 
I can mention for example managing inventory while minning (items dissapear from your mining probe when you switch to ship view, also each mining makes previously gained elements dissapear from the probe, shouldn't they stack? I mean you have whole planet where you could stack them). As for inventory itself, if each room on ship can accomodate 20 resource why can't you use 1 room it to store 5 Cu, 10 Fe, 5 Co? Sorry man, that would be to easy, you have to use one room for each element.   
Overal feeling is that some of game's design choices makes you fail offten just to artificially prolong gameplay and hide game's small content. 
Roguelikes are ruled by luck but in good roguelike game even if you loose you get the feeling that you might do something better next time or you unlock something new which can make your next run easier or at least different (everspace). There is nothing like that here (except for space hulk of your previosus ship which is nice addition).  
Basis of the game is: go to gas giant to gather fuel, pray that its atmosphere won't damage your ship too much and that you get enough fuel to make it worth (totally random). After few lucky attempts you will probably find better ship. At this point the game gets more interesting (and slightly easier) and you have opportunity to at least prepare for some negative random events. Still after unsuccessfull run you are back to square one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049057849', 'num_games_owned': 832, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1611724576}
review: Rogue-like, adventure and survival game set in the universe of nameless stars that lets you explore the cosmos with varied random encounters and a scarcity of resources.   I have really enjoyed my time with the game so far, and I like to chill nature of just jumping from system to system.  There's a learning curve and the different ships all have different difficulty levels for how to get out the gate successfully.  Don't get attached to your ship; get attached to the wonderful art style and narrative direction.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042103654', 'num_games_owned': 2179, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1611340335}
review:
It's one thing to have random encounters and feel like you're in an ongoing struggle to survive, scraping by with a few dozen resources at a time while your fuel and oxygen tanks are constantly near empty, but you're heroically getting by...

... it's entirely a different thing when you think you've hit a good stride and a single random encounter-
1) damages not one, not two, but three of your systems.
2) completely destroys another one and removes it from your ship.
3) deletes technologies you've unlocked.
4) cripples your ship for massive damage.
5) drains your fuel.
6) takes large chunks of your reserve fuel materials.
7) just for good measure, takes small amounts of all your other resources.
8) takes just enough of your iron so you cannot repair some of the things it damaged.
9) also takes what seemed to be a quest-related item of some kind.
10) damages parts of your ship so you also need to repair that.

And effectively is a run killer in a single move because of all this.

There's a sense of "damn, I can do better next time" in a good game... even if it was a string of bad luck that did you in.

This... This just slaps you with "haha you lose." and you stare at it going "right, how was I supposed to not die here?"

author: {'steamid': '76561198049151274', 'num_games_owned': 2149, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 1503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1503, 'last_played': 1610368033}
review:
A masterpiece! Gives you a feel of solitude that many games can't ever deliver, the soundtrack is also perfect for this game, emphasizes your loneliness in space. Being a randomly generated game, you can replay it countless times and not ever get an identical playthrough or layout.

It has a steep learning curve, the Easy difficulty is pretty difficult as well, you are overwhelmed by the many technologies available (about 30) and random encounters that will make you choose options, which can either give you resources, take your vital resources or even damage your ship. You will die many times because you either run out of fuel or oxigen or can't find any planet that would give you the required resource to continue the game.

After a few playthroughs the game gets easier and easier, you'll get to know which ships are better and what upgrades/modules are worth installing, which resources to carry with you. This game will always be a struggle for survival, hunting for resources, random events that can take all that you fought for in no time while you switch solar systems.

Also the alien language spoken in the game has to be learned again in every playthrough, as it's also randomly generated. There's fixed number of dialog words + the name of the minerals/resources in alien language. Everyone in the universe seem to speak the same alien language, so about halfway through your gameplay you'll get to know most of the language already, after that it's a walk in the park as you can trade with aliens get the mysterious Omega element for minerals.

Getting new tech is vital for beating various missions or surviving by reducing your fuel usage, increase the range of your telescope, increas your jump range, the ability to gather fuel from stars, the ability to kill a solar system, jump through blackholes, terraform a rocky planet to gather more resources or meet new aliens.

There's 5 different missions to choose from, playtime for a mission, depending on difficulty, ship, luck and expertise, can take anywhere from 1.5h - 5h (blue or green missions are the shortest, red and yellow require further planning, while finishing the orange is completely random as you need to gather people from planets).

I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes space survival games with strategy elements. I'm glad there was an easy mode for learning the game mechanics, as Normal is even more brutal. It's addictive, I found myself often playing this game until 3 AM in the morning without realizing it's time for bed...

Total playtime to unlock 100% achievements: 22.0 hours, total of 5 complete playthroughs for the 5 main missions on Easy difficulty (luckily there's no difficulty related achievements). This time also includes many failed attempts when I was required to give up after a couple hours of gameplay because I run out of fuel or got a vital module broken and no resource to fix it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048986589', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1609096339}
review: Yes, people compare this game to "FTL: Faster Than Light" a lot but I have no problem with that. "Out There" is simple than FTL (no combats, no crew, it is only you) and that is a welcomed break for me for all the micromanaging you have to do in overcomplicated games I usually play. Plus the graphics in "Out There" are much more beautiful and enjoyable. Still the game is very hard (as FTL) and you will die a lot. Winning is more a matter of luck than stills and tactics. But that is ok, luck is the main factor in roguelike games and lets face it  - "Out There: Î© Edition" is a space roguelike no matter what other tags people put on it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110438632', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1609105691}
review: You check out planets and gas giants, drill and probe then, then refill the things that need to be refilled. Sometime you build things. The biggest and only real challenge I faced was inventory management. This maintenance side-hustle is the device to get to the snippets of story. As my time played indicate it's not for me but it's well presented and you might enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179560647', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 2169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2169, 'last_played': 1607572364}
review:
Pretty frustrating game even on Easy. Feels initially like you are just waiting for the RNG to turn up the right resources with no influence on the outcome. After about 20 hours play I did start to figure out how to move the odds in my favour, and make a bit of a plan. By 36 hours I had got most of the wins and achievements in the game, and could see how to get most of the rest. 

So well worth the small amount of money I paid for it. And worth the time investment in the end. I started playing the phone version, but found the PC version much easier to deal with .

review:
Another game I'm really not any good at, but like anyway. It feels like an FTL style game, but you have more control... or so you think. RNG will still bend you over and plow you dry until you bleed. I was on my third ship, saving humans, and started hucking them overboard to hoard resources to survive. 

And still died. 

5/7, savior of humanity. Would genocide again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975452658', 'num_games_owned': 1699, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1606866189}
review:
What an infuriating game.  I should say right off the bat I dislike roguelikes whose gameplay loop is nothing but relying on dice rolls, because I don't consider the game throwing dice at you as the sole arbiter in deciding whether you are allowed to win today to [i]be[/i] gameplay, but this is the first game I've found where you can randomly lose [i]techology[/i].  More than once I've found a really neat upgrade and then before I even have the opportunity to make it I've already lost the ability to make it.  That ain't fun.

That being said though I [i]love[/i] the art style and the atmosphere, but it's not enough to make up for a fundamentally aggravating gameplay experience and I wouldn't recommend this to anyone but the most die-hard gambling addicts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082375342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1606449023}
review:
I was really trying to like this game
It has an interesting story, variable finals, every decision you make will affect your gameplay. Those things are done so well but that's not it.
The weakest point of this game (for me and for some other guys with negative reviews) is the RNG. It's just so much that it can ruin your run in the worst possible games. My lasts runs were so infuriating that I don't feel like recommending this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072876066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1615518389}
review: It does not matter how you play this game. The only thing that matters is how the game throws dice for you. Great idea, but starts to be frustrating quite quickly. You don't have to plan, you just need to pray.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119779995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1639947110}
review:
While I like this game, I can't recommend it to anyone else. It's kind of like Weird Worlds: Return to Infinite Space, but without all the good stuff and modding ability. As others have mentioned, this game is very unforgiving and highly dependent on luck. I'd venture almost exclusively RNG, and that's no fun. 
The sole advantage is you can play it for five minutes, then go something else with your time.  Get the original WW: RTIS that I mentioned above, then track down all the cool mods for it and enjoy that much, much more.

Attention, ma femme ce n'est pas Alien. Ce que je veux dire, c'est que face Ã  ma femme en colÃ¨re, mÃªme Alien n'en mÃ¨nerait pas large.

De toute faÃ§on, Alien il est pas idiot, il ne s'est jamais mariÃ©.

Remarquez que je le comprend un peu : chez eux la Reine bouffe le mÃ¢le juste aprÃ¨s l'accouplement. Le cÃ´tÃ© positif, c'est qu'Alien ne se fait jamais engueuler parce qu'il a oubliÃ© d'offrir des fleurs pour la Saint Valentin. De toutes les maniÃ¨res, les fleurs, il les aurait bouffÃ©. Les Alien ont une culture culinaire trÃ¨s dÃ©veloppÃ©e.

Enfin donc, dans l'Espace Ã§a crie et Ã§a hurle :

"- Attention la moto !"

"- Trop taaaard ! Prends rendez-vous chez le carrossier !"

"- Attention le radar !"

"- Trop taaaard ! T'inquiÃ¨tes pas, on ne pourra pas m'identifier sur la photo, j'Ã©tais penchÃ© pour ramasser mon dÃ©capsuleur qui Ã©tait tombÃ©. Repasse-moi une canette s'il te plaÃ®t !".

Je dois pourtant avouer que des fois, Ã§a m'arrange quand mÃªme un peu quand elle se met Ã  hurler : Ã§a me tient bien Ã©veillÃ©. Surtout quand dans l'heure prÃ©cÃ©dente, vous avez essayÃ© tant bien que mal de suivre l'Ã©mission qui vous intÃ©ressait Ã  la radio pendant qu'elle vous donnait des nouvelles d'un tas de gens que vous ne connaissez pas, comme ses collÃ¨gues de travail ou bien des personnes avec qui elle voyage en transport en commun.

Enfin, dans le jeu vous Ãªtes seul. Votre vaisseau est assez vite limitÃ© en termes de capacitÃ© cargo, mais on peut trouver d'autres vaisseaux plus tard.

Vous allez beaucoup mourir dans ce jeu. Le plus souvent par manque de carburant  plus rarement par manque d'oxygÃ¨ne ou parce que votre vaisseau est rÃ©duit Ã  l'Ã©tat d'Ã©paves. Mais c'est en forgeant que l'on devient forgeron. 
Ou plutÃ´t comme le disait DÃ©sirÃ© Landru, c'est en chauffant qu'on devient chauffagiste

Ou un truc comme Ã§a.

Donc, le but du jeu c'est d'aller le plus loin possible. Un peu comme quand vous Ãªtes pris en chasse par des motards de la gendarmerie parce que vous avez renversÃ© le radar avec votre vÃ©hicule, mais ce n'est vraiment pas de votre faute parce que vous avez Ã©tÃ© Ã©bloui.

Il y a beaucoup d'alÃ©atoire dans ce jeu. Pour autant, si vous avez la chance de passer rapidement Ã  un vaisseau plus grand, et que vous pouvez le faire Ã©voluer technologiquement, notamment pour augmenter le rayon d'action de vos sauts, vous pourrez terminer l'une des diffÃ©rentes fins possibles dans le jeu.

Et comme le disait DSK Ã  la femme de mÃ©nage du Sofitel de New-York  : "c'est dur, mais pas impossible !"

Enfin, LA QUESTION que tout le monde se pose : est-ce que ce jeu permet de faire de belles rencontres ?

Ã‡a dÃ©pend beaucoup de quel espace on parle, parce que pour moi, je me sentirai plus en sÃ©curitÃ© avec Alien...

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11207, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1601270281}
review:
This is a mobile ported, dumbed down ripoff of FTL with the combat component stripped out.  Ugly retro pixel graphics have been replaced with mediocre cartoony graphics.   

Much like the FTL game this is ripping off, there's no content, it's just a gauntlet of punishing random encounters as you thread your way across various pathways to reach the end goal.  This is easier for lazy developers than having to come up with compelling storyline and content flow. 

Once more we see greedy mobile devs trying to screw over PC gamers. On Steam, this is an eye watering $15 USD (for a crappy mobile game), on app stores, it's $4 USD. Mobile devs must learn PC gamers are not here to be gouged, and can't be expected to pay $11 premium for a mobile game just because it's been lazily dumped on Steam.

review: For the most part i enjoyed the games simplicity and creativity. Although i ran into a few annoying problems like how it got kinda repetitive after a while and that there where some plot errors. The art in the game and the storylines tho make it worth buying but i would take a good long look at it before actually getting it.

review:
A rogue-like choose-your-own-adventure space travel game. 
I enjoyed this game extensively, especially deciphering the cryptographic alien languages. 
The entire game can be played with just a mouse.

The yellow mission is by far the most difficult task to complete, as you must use several technologies learned throughout the galaxy to succeed.

review: This game is stylish and the flavor text is interesting but it is hella unbalanced.  RNG is ridiculously stacked against players.  I have spent nearly 2 hours on this game and I can't even get halfway to the end on easy.  There is no reason for it to be so difficult.  It could be really fun if it was re-balanced.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079530646', 'num_games_owned': 457, 'num_reviews': 218, 'playtime_forever': 619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1449703107}
review: Serious lack of gameplay and the gameplay that is present is not engaging. You are stranded in space and need to find your way back to civilization. You hop from planet to planet, mine resources and guess what planet leads to your way out. Guessing wrong can lead you to a dead end which ends your game. Limited inventory space leads to limited resources, the latter has to compete for inventory space together with ship upgrades (like drills, radar, engine etc). So this is mainly an inventory management game. Crudely, it's FTL where the combat is replaced by mining. It got nice artwork, the atmosphere is relaxing, great concept but gameplay is simplistic (what you expect from a mobile game).

author: {'steamid': '76561198042140942', 'num_games_owned': 95, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3397, 'last_played': 1596726004}
review:
Inventory Management Puzzle: The Game.

Crux of the game is surviving long enough to get the upgrades that improve your ship's efficiency and range. After that it just becomes a grind to the end of the map, since once you've seen one system, you've seen them all. Learning the language is helpful for getting tech/etc. from aliens through trading, but unlike all the other words in the game, you can only learn the words for the trading items through trial and error, which adds arbitrary difficulty to the game since you can't repeat interactions on a given planet. Very bland overall; definitely not worth $15. Only even consider trying the game if you have a 75%-off coupon, otherwise leave this one alone.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991556719', 'num_games_owned': 681, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1595184188}
review:
Unfortunately, RNG reigns supreme. The premise is interesting, it involves mainly around resource management while you jump from planet to planet and keep your ship in one piece. Along the way you'll run into random encounters that unveil a bit of the storyline or force you to make a decision. The game also punishes (or rewards) you for no reason whatsoever without any of your doing as is common in these games. Very annoying to suddenly take 20 damage. Very pleasant to receive 100% oxygen but really, just artificially spiking up the difficulty without providing a challenge that can be overcome means nothing in the end to the player. It's poor game design.

The game doesn't feature any combat whatsoever which means that although similar to FTL and Derelict, you'll mostly spend your time looking at the same type of planets and clicking the same few buttons over and over without any thing to get really good at. Yes, you'll learn to plan more effectively but that's about it, you can't outperform random encounters any better than the guy that just started unless, of course, you memorize all of them. Not anyone idea's of fun, I reckon.

The art direction is okay, the music and sound is atmospheric and the storyline does seem interesting. You can uncover bits of alien language but unfortunately, these are lost when you die so you'll have to rediscover the language all over again. Some persistence here would have been nice. You can, however, select an option before you start your game that will allow you to board your old ships when you die. Nice touch.

I ended up playing a game where I had traded in my ship for a ship that could jump with very little fuel and oxygen requirement. I ran out of fuel because I couldn't jump far enough to get to the next system and I ended up running low jumping back and forth trying to find a way out Fortunately, I ran into yet an even more powerful ship and boarded that one and continued playing for a bit, jumping from system to system (ones I had already visited) to get back to where I left off just to find out that this ship couldn't make the jump either! 

There simply wasn't a way forward no matter where I went. I went backwards to check and no, couldn't jump there either. I figured that perhaps I could just buy another "space folder" but no, you can't actually upgrade your ship unless you've discovered the technology beforehand during your current game.

This is where I pressed the quit button and the thumbs down. RNG to the point where it can break the game is obviously there to hide the lack of skill in writing a half-decent AI to provide the player with an interesting challenge. Might as well play a slotmachine, at least you'll be able to finish your game each round.

I did not pay full price for this game and neither should you. it is definitely NOT worth the asking price to any degree.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030755187', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1597717188}
review:
This game is fun, quick, and hard. Really enjoy playing in the moments where I have 10+ min to blow off (after 4 hours, that's quite a few runs) - still have not reached earth yet... oh well.

BIGGEST COMPLAINT about the game is that its audio is in MONO!!! I get it for mobile games, but common - sound designers and music composers really work in a stereo field, I would think most of us play with headphones or at least speakers - can we please make a stereo version of the audio for this!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198070580358', 'num_games_owned': 491, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1590275853}
review:
It might be ok for mobile gaming (i dunno i don't play games on my phone) but for PC it's too simple. Gameplay consists of:
- reading tons of boring text written in comic sans font 
- drag and dropping squares with chemical elements designations
- clicking on stars and planets. 
Your progress depends mostly on RNG and you don't really have to put any effort. I have no idea why this thing has positive reviews.

I think steam should warn players with huge red letters on the store page that this a mobile game, i wouldn't buy it if i knew.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074613709', 'num_games_owned': 824, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 1006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1006, 'last_played': 1589974282}
review:
I've known this game on mobile for like 8 years and i'm pretty happy about the PC Version. Only problem for me would be the price, get it on a sale !

The game might be super-random at times and it might be hard to get to certain objectives but once you start to understand how the game works it's pretty easy to do everything. Look for guides/wiki on internet, you'll get most of the knowledge you need to make decent runs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198439796494', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1676140110}
review:
Very atmospheric game about space as it should be:

- lost all my fuel (big ship) - dead.
- lost all my oxygen - dead.
- at the far end of the map i have broken my super-duper engine and had no way to fix it, it works, but jumps poor - dead.
- did not find Fe on planets - dead.
- long jump twice - at destination no Gas Giant, at nearby systems too, so no fuel - dead.

Being a developer (web stack, not game dev) , sometimes i thinking about own game about space - and "Out there" is a game I like.
